content: The speaker is discussing a proof of the Gauss-Bonnet Theorem using the Hopf-Poincaré Theorem. They explain how one can integrate over the boundary of a collection of balls around singularities and obtain the sum of the degrees of the vector field at these points. The speaker also mentions that one could have proven the theorem by triangulating the space and examining the curvature, which would have resulted in a formula involving faces, edges, and vertices. They also mention that the theorem is well-defined and the differential of the integral is well-controlled, even though the vector field f has nothing to do with the differential.
